conversation:
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: A Sharran.
Narrator: *Isobel. The same name as Ketheric Thorm's daughter - the one whose sarcophagus you found empty in the family mausoleum.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Player: I thought I smelled a Selûnite.
Isobel: At your service.
Isobel: Frankly, I'm surprised you're willing to help us. Your kind aren't known for their decency - particularly when a Sharran curse is our greatest obstacle.
Isobel: But if you are who I think you are, I'd be a fool to reject your help. The True Soul with... well, a soul. Imagine.
Player: I'm glad you've remembered who needs whose help here.
Isobel: Oh - aren't you looking for a protection spell?
Player: I need nothing from a Selûnite.
Isobel: But any others who travel with you may not agree. Do it for them at least - you will need all the help you can get out there.
Player: Silently petition Lady Shar for guidance.
Narrator: *She offers you nothing.*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we?
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

Narrator: *You don't sleep well, flitting between dreams and nightmares.*
Narrator: *Maybe you wake up because you know something is wrong. Or maybe you just get lucky.*
Astarion: ...Shit.
NodeContext: Hunched over the player's bedroll, about to bite someone, but they've just woken up and are looking up at you. More deadpan than urgent.
Astarion: No no - it's not what it looks like, I swear!
Astarion: I wasn't going to hurt you! I just needed - well, blood.
Narrator: *There, in dim firelight, you see him for what he really is: a vampire. A slave to sanguine hunger.*
Player: How long since you killed someone? Days? Hours?
Astarion: I've never killed anyone! Well, not for food.
Astarion: I feed on animals. Boars, deer, kobolds - whatever I can get.
Astarion: But it's not enough. Not if I have to fight. I feel so weak.
Astarion: If I just had a little blood, I could think clearer. Fight better. Please.
Narrator: *A strange sensation courses through you, and your companion's mind unfolds, secrets half-revealed.*
Player: Push into his mind, searching for the truth.
Astarion: I - what's this? What's happening?
Narrator: *The presence deep in your mind is awake, unblinking. This is it. A single word pervades your consciousness: 'Soon'.*
Narrator: *His mind opens up, revealing cracked and quivering memories. At their heart, you see dark eyes, commanding you to feed.*
Narrator: *You open your mouth and bite down. Not into a tender neck, but into the twisting body of a rat - the only thing your master lets you eat.*
Player: Why didn't you tell me you were a vampire?
Player: Why didn't you tell me?
Astarion: At best, I was sure you'd say no. More likely, you'd ram a stake through my ribs.
Astarion: No, I needed you to trust me. And you can trust me.
Player: I do. I believe you.
Astarion: Thank you. Do you think you could trust me just a little further?
Astarion: I only need a taste, I swear.
Player: All right, but go too far and I'll drive a stake through your chest.
Astarion: Urgh! Gods! Another drop and I would've burnt a hole from lips to navel. I thought we had that fire under control?
Player: Must be the infernal engine. Sorry, Astarion, I can't help you.
Astarion: Clearly.
Astarion: Safe to say this will never happen again.
Astarion: I'll go and find something on four legs to eat, I suppose.
Astarion: See you in the morning.
Player: No. Leave and never return.

Astarion: Now that you know what I am, I should tell you that Cazador was more than just a slaver.
Player: You said he was your master?
Astarion: My old master. Before the mind flayers took me from him. Before this strange, twisted freedom.
Astarion: Cazador Szarr is a vampire lord in Baldur's Gate. The patriarch of his coven and a monster obsessed with power.
Astarion: Not political power or military power - I mean power over people. The power to control them completely.
Astarion: He turned me nearly two hundred years ago. I became his spawn and he became my tormentor.
Player: How were you turned? Did he attack you?
Astarion: Not him, no. A gang of thugs attacked me, angry about a ruling that I'd handed down as magistrate.
Astarion: They beat me to death's door when Cazador appeared. He chased them off and offered to save me. To give me eternal life.
Astarion: Given that my choices were 'eternal life' or 'bleed to death on the street', I took him up on the offer.
Astarion: It was only afterwards I realised just how long 'eternity' could be.
Player: Not a good master, I take it?
Astarion: He had me go out into Baldur's Gate to fetch him the most beautiful souls I could find.
Astarion: It was a fun little ritual of his - I'd bring them back and he'd ask if I wanted to dine with him. And if I said yes, he'd serve me a dead, putrid rat.
Astarion: Of course if I said no, he'd have me flayed. Hard to say which was worse.

Astarion: My point is simple...
Astarion: The mind flayers aren't the only monsters out there. They're not even the only ones hunting us.
Astarion: All I'm asking is that you keep your eyes open. And watch out for anything lurking in the shadows.

Astarion: Not political power or military power - I mean power over people. The power to control them completely.
Astarion: He turned me nearly two hundred years ago. I became his spawn and he became my tormentor.
Player: How were you turned? Did he attack you?
Astarion: Not him, no. A gang of thugs attacked me, angry about a ruling that I'd handed down as magistrate.
Astarion: They beat me to death's door when Cazador appeared. He chased them off and offered to save me. To give me eternal life.
Astarion: Given that my choices were 'eternal life' or 'bleed to death on the street', I took him up on the offer.
Astarion: It was only afterwards I realised just how long 'eternity' could be.
Player: You've been a slave ever since?
Astarion: A vampire's spawn is less than a slave. They're a puppet.
Astarion: We have no choice but to obey our masters' commands. They speak and our bodies react - it's all part of the deal.
Astarion: Sometimes he'd order us to submit to torture. Sometimes he'd have us torture ourselves. Whatever his weathervane mood settled on.
Player: That sounds terrible. I'm so sorry.
Astarion: Thank you, but this isn't about sympathy. It's about knowing what we might be up against.
Astarion: The mind flayers aren't the only monsters out there. And they might not be the only ones hunting us.
Astarion: All I'm asking is that you keep your eyes open. And watch out for anything lurking in the shadows.
Player: Oh no, my friend. If vampires come looking for you, you're on your own.

Astarion: I want to thank you.
Player: For being so wonderful in bed?
Astarion: For what you said while I was in front of that vile drow.
Astarion: I spent two hundred years using my body to lure pretty things back for my Master. What I wanted, how I felt about what I was doing, it never mattered.
Astarion: You could have asked me to do the same - to throw myself at her, what I wanted be damned. But you didn't. And I'm grateful.
Player: I was hoping that as reward for my support you'd throw yourself at me.
Astarion: I- I'm not sure if I should.
Astarion: I don't think I want you to think of me in terms of sex.
Astarion: I don't know if I want anyone to.
Player: I'm not like all the others, I promise.
Astarion: I suppose it has felt different with you...
Astarion: I suppose... If this is what you want, then I shall provide.

Astarion: He turned me nearly two hundred years ago. I became his spawn and he became my tormentor.
Player: How were you turned? Did he attack you?
Astarion: Not him, no. A gang of thugs attacked me, angry about a ruling that I'd handed down as magistrate.
Astarion: They beat me to death's door when Cazador appeared. He chased them off and offered to save me. To give me eternal life.
Astarion: Given that my choices were 'eternal life' or 'bleed to death on the street', I took him up on the offer.
Astarion: It was only afterwards I realised just how long 'eternity' could be.
Player: Not a good master, I take it?
Astarion: He had me go out into Baldur's Gate to fetch him the most beautiful souls I could find.
Astarion: It was a fun little ritual of his - I'd bring them back and he'd ask if I wanted to dine with him. And if I said yes, he'd serve me a dead, putrid rat.
Astarion: Of course if I said no, he'd have me flayed. Hard to say which was worse.
Player: That sounds terrible. I'm so sorry.
Astarion: Thank you, but this isn't about sympathy. It's about knowing what we might be up against.
Astarion: The mind flayers aren't the only monsters out there. And they might not be the only ones hunting us.

Araj Oblodra: Araj Oblodra, trader in blood and the sanguineous arts. It is a pleasure to stand before a True Soul. And your pale companion.
NodeContext: With a bow. (Araj Oblodra = a-RADJ o-BLOD-ruh)
Araj Oblodra: I'd like to offer my services, if you're willing?
Player: I'm listening.
Araj Oblodra: Put plainly - I'd like your blood. A vial of True Soul's blood, specifically.
Araj Oblodra: With one drop, I can brew a rather potent potion for you. The rest, I keep for myself.
Player: No, I'm not interested.
Araj Oblodra: I'm here should you change your mind.
Araj Oblodra: There we are. All of your very best traits in a bottle. Use it well!
Araj Oblodra: Although perhaps there's one more thing we could discuss: your vampiric friend.
Astarion: Don't worry, we're all friends under the Absolute. I won't bite.
Araj Oblodra: Oh I'd prefer if you did.
Araj Oblodra: I assume he belongs to you?
Player: Excuse me? He's his own person.

Araj Oblodra: Do you have a name, spawn?
Astarion: Astarion, but hold on-
Araj Oblodra: Good. Now, Astarion, I've dreamt of being bitten by a vampire since I was a young girl.
Astarion: I'm sorry? You want to be bitten?
Araj Oblodra: To feel your life's blood slipping away? To dance on the edge between life and death? Yes, I want it.
Araj Oblodra: I'll even compensate you - a potion of legendary power that forever increases the strength of the one who consumes it.
Araj Oblodra: It's not for sale, but it's yours if you bite me.
Astarion: I will have to decline.
Araj Oblodra: Excuse me? This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and you're squandering it.

Araj Oblodra: Can't you talk some sense into your obstinate charge?

Astarion: Because there's something wrong with her blood. I can smell it from here - it's rank.

Astarion: I... I suppose you have a point.
Astarion: Fine, I'll do it.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: I spoke to Nettie - she said you could help me with the parasite in my head.
Halsin: Parasite in your head...? You mean you have one of them?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I escaped from an illithid ship after being infected. Maybe the process was interrupted.
Halsin: Perhaps... but I wouldn't want to place all my faith in blind luck.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: Tell me what you've learned about the tadpoles' origins.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: At least I know what to do now. Thank you.
Halsin: Wait - I could help you find a cure... but I need to settle matters here first.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: The other druids are dead, by my hand.
Halsin: What...? How? Why?! Explain yourself at once!
Player: They left me no choice. I had to defend myself.
Halsin: Then... then it is as you say. They forgot their principles; you had no choice. I will mourn them when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: It's too late to merely kill this horde's leadership - their forces are already marching. If you want me to help, you need to help me first.
Halsin: You must get ahead of them, muster the defences.
Player: Very well. I'll go rescue the grove.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player enters a gore-soaked alcove and approaches the displacer.There's various severed heads on display - people and monsters. A pile of eviscerated corpses forms a throne-chaise.
There's suddenly a loud click from above (implied to be the orthon racking/loading its crossbow). The player looks up.
The orthon looms on a gallery/crumpling floor overlooking the alcove. It aims a crossbow at the player. Flanking it are several merregons.
There's suddenly a loud click from above (implied to be the orthon racking/loading its crossbow). The player looks up.

Yurgir: What's this? Fresh entertainment.
Yurgir: But you're too fresh for this place, aren't you? You've got the stench of the Hells about you - the stench of home. And a whiff of the surface besides.
Yurgir: A servant of Zariel, if I'm not mistaken. I'd know the stench of her infernal machinery anywhere.
Yurgir: You trying to burrow back home, little rabbit?
Player: What do you know about infernal machinery?
Yurgir: Only what I can smell. And whatever engine burns within you is grinding to an inevitable explosion. Burning and fear - you reek with it.
Yurgir: ...There's something else, almost hidden by your fear-stink... cherries, musk... and sulphur.
NodeContext: Sniffing the air at the start, detecting something - then erupting with fury at the end on 'sulphur'.
Yurgir: Raphael! I can smell him all over you. Where is he?!
NodeContext: Furious
Player: Wait - you know Raphael?
Yurgir: That perfumed trickster swindled me - trapped me.
Player: He wants you dead.
Yurgir: Where is he? Spit it out - Now.
Astarion: What are you doing? The devil told us to kill this thing, so let's stop chatting and kill it.
Player: Let's share our experiences about Raphael. Perhaps we can help each other.
Yurgir: Bargaining, are you? A Kara-Tur warlord once tried the same - I made him watch as I ate his concubines and young, then fashioned a codpiece from his skull.
Yurgir: You can't help. It's not just walls that keep me here. Not the traps, the dark or the creatures it hides. Something stronger holds me - a contract.
Yurgir: Either I fulfil the contract, die trying... or forfeit my freedom. If I leave this place now, I'll become Raphael's slave.
Player: I happen to be an expert in such deals - and there is always a loophole.
Yurgir: Raphael is no foolish story-devil, his mind is different. Sneaky. Listen...
Yurgir: Spill all the blood sworn to the night.
Silence all prayers; smother each rite.
NodeContext: singing, a cappella
Yurgir: Wander Shar's halls; hungry to slay;
Leave no Justiciar alive to obey.
NodeContext: singing, a cappella
Yurgir: Leave none to hear it, then be set free;
This song is your oath, swear, swear it to me.
NodeContext: singing, a cappella
Narrator: *Well, that explains where all the Dark Justiciars went.*
: False
Yurgir: ...That's it.
NodeContext: A little knowing (double meaning in 'that's it' - the song has ended, but he also thinks he's stumbled upon a revelation in the lyrics.)
Gale: So he's the one who killed all the Dark Justiciars. Alone. Might not want to get on his bad side.
Player: That was awful - perhaps you should stick to killing.
Yurgir: Oh, I intend to. The lyrics are clear - all who hear the song must die.
Yurgir: Time to die.
Narrator: *You feel your patron's prickling flame at the back of your mind - and its diabolic words on your tongue. It wants to help.*
Player: There must be something you missed. Let me search this place for you.
: True
Yurgir: I spent a century roaming these halls - I spilled every drop of Dark Justiciar blood that there was to spill. And you think you can do better?

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.
Jaheira: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.
Jaheira: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: It's rare people look at me and see 'hope'.
Jaheira: The light is rather dim, out here in the shadowlands. The point remains:
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Jaheir takes the glass from the table.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute.
Jaheira: Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: Absolutely not. Marcus is a danger to you all.
: False
Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer.
Jaheira: But you're far from the most eccentric drinking companion I've had. I'd like to know more. Cheers.
Jaheira: To your very good health.
Player: Smell the wine.
: True
Narrator: *You perceive a faint hint of Klauthgrass, a herb that is said to elicit the truth. Jaheira smiles at you knowingly.*
Jaheira: It doesn't spoil the taste, if that's what you're wondering.
Player: I was actually wondering if it would affect me. Poisons often struggle.
Jaheira: Well, consider this an experiment, then.
Player: Drink the wine.

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: By your words, any virtue delaying patience would itself be unvirtuous.
Havkelaag: And therein lies your fault: you would have us argue in circles until the egg hatches naturally. Time we do not have.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: Patience does not delay, it simply tempers virtue. Curtails it from excess.
Havkelaag: A cautious, hesitant instinct. One I am afraid we do not have time for.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: An experiment like this will only confirm the surface dwellers' suspicion of us.

Astarion: There you are, I was just thinking about you. And that delicious moment we shared the other night.
Player: The moment when you bit me?
Astarion: The very same. I've had this condition for two centuries, but truth be told? You were my first.
Astarion: In all these years, I've only ever fed on beasts. Drinking the blood of thinking creatures is a different thing entirely.
Astarion: You were delectable. And now I just can't help but wonder how the others taste.
Player: They might not be as open to the idea as I was.

Astarion: But the gith? What in the hells would she taste like?

Shadowheart: Never you mind.
Player: You're a Shar worshipper, aren't you?

Shadowheart: I worship Shar, the Mistress of the Night.
Shadowheart: Don't make a fuss, Selûnite - we may be at odds, but I have more important concerns than you right now.
Karlach: Fantastic. Monsters in our minds, and around our campfire.
Player: Don't make a big fuss...? You've been lying to me!
Shadowheart: A lie of omission at most. I'm sure you have some skeletons of your own hidden away.
Shadowheart: Secrecy is everything for Shar's children. It's our code, our creed, our shield.
Shadowheart: I'm not sorry I kept this from you. Not one bit.
Shadowheart: Though perhaps that might change, if you can show an open mind.
Player: I can't trust you. Best if we travel separately for now.

Ward Magmar: Another round, Stickshit.

NodeContext: VO NOTE:Magmar should sound drunk

Stickpit walks off screen with both mugs

NodeContext: To Skickpit
Karlach: Cruelty like that poisons the soul 'til one day, you drop dead - or the person you're fucking with snaps and puts a sword in your eye.
Ward Magmar: Heard you tore Nere t'bits. But that don't make us friends.
Ward Magmar: Prick-squeak - go tell your True Soul chums we won't move a pebble.
Player: How dare you enslave my people? They deserve dignity, not servitude.

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered.
He Who Was: Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: Let's see what she has to say first.
He Who Was: Careful - for a serpent in life is a serpent in death.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Wyll: Not as if you can relate to the killing urge, can you? Hmph - I can taste the hypocrisy from here.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: Don't blame others for what you did.
Madeline: You didn't see it. Didn't see what the Dark Justiciar did.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: There's nothing you need do. This wasn't your fault - I promise.

Dolly Dolly Dolly: My name? My name is Dolly thrice; now won't you free me from this vice?

Astarion: You know, I was just thinking about you. Remembering our little encounter in the night.
Player: When you tried to bite me?
Astarion: The very same. It obviously put me off your neck, but now I can't help but wonder how the others taste.
Astarion: Not that anyone's volunteered, it's just an idle fancy.
Player: I wouldn't expect any volunteers either.
Astarion: Alas. It doesn't hurt to ponder the question, though.
Astarion: I don't think they'd volunteer, of course, but it doesn't make me any less curious.
Astarion: I'm all too familiar with Gale's blood, unfortunately. I can't recommend it.
Astarion: But the gith? What in the hells would she taste like?
Player: I'd prefer a beer, if it's all the same to you.
Astarion: Yes, heavens forbid we'd have an interesting conversation.
Astarion: Still, I am intrigued by the possibilities...
Player: Keep your eyes to yourself. You'll make people nervous.
Astarion: Relax, we're just talking.
Astarion: So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?
Player: Are you really asking which of our companions I'd eat?

[description] CinematicNodeContext: shot of player and whatever remaining gnomes are alive panting, catching their breath. Wulbren appears and claps slowly
Wulbren Bongle: That was a hell of a show, my friend. Watchers collapse in the street as we speak, and the Foundry?
Wulbren Bongle: The scent of runepowder drifts through the city like a warm embrace - I see my bomb did the trick.
Wulbren Bongle: Watchers collapse in the street as we speak. The city thanks you - I thank you.
Wulbren Bongle: But it's not over - so long as a single parasitic Gondian remains, Baldur's Gate is under threat.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Enough, Wulbren! Gortash enslaved us, forced us to build his Steel Watchers - but no more.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home, and to hold my daughter.
Player: What about Gortash? What if he forces you to build up his Steel Watch once more?
Gondian Zanner Toobin: I will be long gone from this wretched city before that happens. I am no threat - I am... nothing.
Wulbren Bongle: Please - if a Gondian told me the sky was blue, I'd look outside and check.
Wulbren Bongle: Toobin will lie, torment, and scheme until his dying breath. Kill him - or the Ironhands will.
Wulbren Bongle: You Gondians will lie, scheme, and torment this city until your dying breaths. Let's end this.
NodeContext: the mask has truly gone, we see wulbren for what he is - cruel, spiteful and viscious
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren - enough! I won't watch as you poison your soul - and the brilliant future that remains to the Ironhand Gnomes.
Barcus Wroot: I thought the Ironhand Gnomes had corrupted you, Wulbren. Now I wonder if it wasn't the other way around.
Barcus Wroot: Kill Toobin, and you kill all we love: Collaboration. Challenge. Solving problems with the power of reason, creativity, and invention.
Barcus Wroot: I still want to believe you're better than that, Wulbren. But even I am having my doubts.
Player: Wulbren makes a good point - you must die for the city, Gondians.

Zevlor: Ngh. Mragreshem.
NodeContext: mrag-RESH-em. Means 'shithead' in infernal. Zevlor has just woken up after being punched in the face by Aradin. He's groggy and pissed off.

NodeContext: Disgust in his voice. His idiot enemy clocked him.
Player: Are you all right?
Zevlor: I'll survive a sore jaw. Particularly if it's rid the grove of Aradin.
Zevlor: Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out.
Zevlor: This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Those goblins - have there been many attacks like that?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore.
Zevlor: They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road.
Zevlor: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Karlach: Gods, these are those tiefs? Their whole city was dragged into Avernus for a while. Zariel was delighted. When they made it back out, I'd hoped they got their happy ending.
Narrator: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*
Player: If your people survived that, they'll survive anything.
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

Zevlor: How easily such a nasty word slips through the mouth of someone you thought you knew.
Zevlor: We thought we'd found sanctuary here, but the druids have determined to turn us out.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

Zevlor: You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place.
Zevlor: Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.

Player: I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

Player: Here - take it.

He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'd like to hear her story first - I imagine it's quite the tale.
He Who Was: Careful - for a serpent in life is a serpent in death.
He Who Was: Witness her.

Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.

Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.

Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence?
Raphael: It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on.
Raphael: In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope.
Raphael: He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored.
Raphael: He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: Stop stalling.
Raphael: As you wish. Brace yourself, Astarion - we're about to unveil your destiny.
Raphael: And why would he want to walk away? This is his destiny.
Raphael: As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr.
Raphael: In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed.
Raphael: The Rite of Profane Ascension.
Raphael: It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical.
Raphael: If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant.
Raphael: All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living.
Raphael: The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike you, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun.
Raphael: But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend.
Raphael: Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air.
Raphael: The only missing ingredient is Astarion.
Raphael: You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life.
Raphael: And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.
NodeContext: [Tarik] snaps fingers at the end of the line.
Astarion: Hmm...
Player: You don't need to go back to Cazador - you're with me now.
Astarion: Do you think it's so simple?
Astarion: What do you think I should do?
Player: We can't let Cazador complete that ritual. He could unleash terrible horrors.
Astarion: The end of my life among them. Just when I was starting to enjoy it.
Astarion: He'll never leave me alone. I didn't think he would when I was just one more wretched toy for him to play with.
Astarion: But if I'm the key to this power he craves, he'll hunt me to the ends of Faerûn.
Astarion: I need to take the fight to him.
Astarion: And I need you to help me.
Player: After we dealt with our tadpole problem, yes, I'll help you then.
Astarion: Once we deal with the tadpole, I'll be back to my nocturnal self. When you're being hunted by vampires, the dark is the worst place to hide.
Astarion: I need to deal with Cazador while I still have any kind of advantage over him.
Astarion: If you won't risk taking him on for my sake, think of the innocent souls he'll sacrifice in this ritual.
Player: We're done talking about this, Astarion. My decision is made.

Sazza: It ain't our fault, General! We did as we were told -
Disciple Z'rell: The facts suggest otherwise. You were ordered to retrieve the artefact - you failed to do so.
Sazza: We did as you lot told us. Minthara's the one who -
Disciple Z'rell: Enough!
NodeContext: Via mind meld
Narrator: *A blast of mental energy washes over you, filling the room. Your tadpole squirms, urging you to obey.*
Disciple Z'rell: You failed to retrieve the artefact. You failed to protect your True Soul. You do not deserve to live.
Player: Don't kill them! They're loyal followers of the Absolute.
Player: Hear, hear!
Narrator: *As the General's attention shifts to you, a memory stirs - a memory of this room, and his voice raised in anger.*
Ketheric Thorm: I'm surprised to see you again, True Soul. You are here to assist and not to meddle, I trust.
Ketheric Thorm: I would remind you that while in my halls, you obey me - just as you would any other Chosen.
Ketheric Thorm: I'm sure you will enjoy watching my justice enacted.
Ketheric Thorm: You have to take what pleasure you can, after all, in your diminished state.
Narrator: *His smirk says everything and nothing at once. 'I know exactly who you are, and I will never tell.'*
Player: You know me, General?
Ketheric Thorm: Better than you know yourself, it seems.
Ketheric Thorm: But we are here to deal with these goblins, not to speak of your past.
Ketheric Thorm: Kill them. Quickly.
NodeContext: Standing up to leave
Ketheric Thorm: Kill the goblins, too.
NodeContext: An afterthought, as he stands up to leave
Darra: What? No!
Drenn: You creaking old bag of shit!
NodeContext: Drenn grabs a halberd from a surprised guard and throws it at Ketheric.
Ketheric Thorm: Hmm.
NodeContext: KETHERIC stares at the halberd embedded in his chest in shock. Then, after a beat, he grunts in anger and pain as with one hand he grabs the halberd and pulls it free. The wound left by the blade is just a glowing purple gash, which disappears before our eyes, leaving his chest without even a scratch.
Disciple Z'rell: I'm so sorry, my lord. She's an unbeliever - outside my control.
NodeContext: Very apologetic - this should never have happened
Ketheric Thorm: Try again.
NodeContext: Ketheric drops the halberd on the ground and challenges the goblin.
Ketheric Thorm: Huh.
NodeContext: Just been stabbed, but is invulnerable.
Drenn: No - NO!
NodeContext: terrified - you know you're about to die
Ketheric Thorm: Dispose of the rest as you see fit.
Ketheric Thorm: Or better yet - put that True Soul to use. They've proven themselves reliable.
Disciple Z'rell: Of course, my lord. Thank you.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Ketheric leaves the throne room
Disciple Z'rell: You heard the General. The goblins are yours - deal with them however you wish.
Player: Nod curtly.
Disciple Z'rell: Here, in the seat of the Absolute's power, your authority over them is complete. They will obey any command.
Disciple Z'rell: Report to me upstairs when you're done.
Sazza: You wouldn't hurt me, would you? We're mates, me and you. Practically family!
Player: I'll give you a fair chance. Fight me - you either die, or you kill me and you're free to go.

Havkelaag: Well met. What can the Society of Brilliance do for you?
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.
Havkelaag: Enough of your kind have wreaked destruction on this plane for me to be confident in my assertion.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you, too, follow the teachings of Bahamut. Why him?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: An experiment like this will only confirm the surface dwellers' suspicion of us.
Havkelaag: Of course it won't. If anything, it will do quite the opposite. The academic institutions up here will finally be forced to take us seriously.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered.
He Who Was: Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'd like to hear her story first - I imagine it's quite the tale.
He Who Was: Careful - for a serpent in life is a serpent in death.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Shadowheart: Oh, come on now - it happens to the best of us, from time to time.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: Don't blame others for what you did.
Madeline: You didn't see it. Didn't see what the Dark Justiciar did.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Stab yourself. Rip your stomach open. Feel the pain of your friends - only then will you be free.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
: True
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Start stabbing, and don't stop until I say so.
Madeline: Ah! I'm sorry.
NodeContext: Ah! is a noise of pain as she stabs herself in the stomach and then pulls out the knife. 'I'm sorry' is said in clear pain.
Madeline: Argh. I'm so sorry.
NodeContext: stabs herself again on 'Argh', noise of pain. I'm so so sorry is half crying as she's in agony.
Player: Stop. You've done enough.

Astarion: There you are, I was just thinking about you. And that delicious moment we shared the other night.
Player: The moment when you bit me?
Astarion: The very same. I've had this condition for two centuries, but truth be told? You were my first.
Astarion: In all these years, I've only ever fed on beasts. Drinking the blood of thinking creatures is a different thing entirely.
Astarion: You were delectable. And now I just can't help but wonder how the others taste.

Astarion: I don't think they'd volunteer, of course, but it doesn't make me any less curious.

Astarion: But the gith? What in the hells would she taste like?

Zevlor: Now that's settled.
Zevlor: Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him.
Zevlor: Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor.
Zevlor: And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: Please - it's just Wyll.
Zevlor: Well met, by whatever name. Though I'm afraid that's all the welcome we can give you.
Zevlor: Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out.
Zevlor: This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: I won't be staying long - I just need to find a healer.
Zevlor: They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road.
Zevlor: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
Narrator: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*
Player: Found sanctuary here, did you?
Zevlor: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again.

Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: By your words, any virtue delaying patience would itself be unvirtuous.
Havkelaag: And therein lies your fault: you would have us argue in circles until the egg hatches naturally. Time we do not have.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence?
Raphael: It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on.
Raphael: In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope.
Raphael: He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored.
Raphael: He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.

Raphael: And why would he want to walk away? This is his destiny.
Raphael: As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr.
Raphael: In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed.
Raphael: The Rite of Profane Ascension.
Raphael: It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical.
Raphael: If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant.
Raphael: All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living.
Raphael: The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike you, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun.
Raphael: But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend.
Raphael: Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air.
Raphael: The only missing ingredient is Astarion.
Raphael: You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life.
Raphael: And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.

Astarion: He'll never leave me alone. I didn't think he would when I was just one more wretched toy for him to play with.

Astarion: I need to take the fight to him.
Astarion: And I need you to help me.

Astarion: I need to deal with Cazador while I still have any kind of advantage over him.
Astarion: If you won't risk taking him on for my sake, think of the innocent souls he'll sacrifice in this ritual.

Astarion: You know, I was just thinking about you. Remembering our little encounter in the night.
Player: When you tried to bite me?
Astarion: The very same. It obviously put me off your neck, but now I can't help but wonder how the others taste.
Astarion: Not that anyone's volunteered, it's just an idle fancy.
Player: I wouldn't expect any volunteers either.
Astarion: Alas. It doesn't hurt to ponder the question, though.
Astarion: I don't think they'd volunteer, of course, but it doesn't make me any less curious.
Astarion: Take Wyll, for example. A man of the people, very palatable, like a sweet cider.
Astarion: But the gith? What in the hells would she taste like?
Player: I'd prefer a beer, if it's all the same to you.
Astarion: Yes, heavens forbid we'd have an interesting conversation.
Astarion: Still, I am intrigued by the possibilities...
Player: This is still theoretical, right?
Astarion: Absolutely. A mere thought experiment.
Astarion: So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?
Player: Are you really asking which of our companions I'd eat?
Astarion: Oh no, don't be disgusting.
Astarion: I just mean a sip of their blood. No mastication required.
Astarion: So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?
Player: Gale, no question.
Astarion: I'm all too familiar with Gale's blood, unfortunately. I can't recommend it.
Astarion: But the gith? What in the hells would she taste like?
Player: I'd prefer a beer, if it's all the same to you.
Astarion: Yes, heavens forbid we'd have an interesting conversation.
Astarion: Still, I am intrigued by the possibilities...
Player: Keep your eyes to yourself. You'll make people nervous.
Astarion: Relax, we're just talking.

Player: I much prefer eating flesh to blood.
Astarion: I do appreciate your enthusiasm, but let's try to restrain ourselves a little.
Astarion: I just mean a sip of their blood. No mastication required.

Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence?
Raphael: It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on.
Raphael: In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope.
Raphael: He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored.
Raphael: He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: Are you sure you want to know, Astarion? Maybe it's best left in the past.
Astarion: Even if I wanted to walk away from all of this, I can't. Cazador won't let me.
Raphael: And why would he want to walk away? This is his destiny.
Raphael: As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr.
Raphael: In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed.
Raphael: The Rite of Profane Ascension.
Raphael: It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical.
Raphael: If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant.
Raphael: All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living.
Raphael: The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike Astarion, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun.
Raphael: But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend.
Raphael: Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air.
Raphael: The only missing ingredient is Astarion.
Raphael: You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life.
Raphael: And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.
NodeContext: [Tarik] snaps fingers at the end of the line.
Astarion: Hmm...
Player: Cazador is a piece of shit. We're going to stop him.
Astarion: Do you think it's so simple?
Astarion: What do you think I should do?
Player: We can't let Cazador complete that ritual. He could unleash terrible horrors.
Astarion: The end of my life among them. Just when I was starting to enjoy it.
Astarion: He'll never leave me alone. I didn't think he would when I was just one more wretched toy for him to play with.
Astarion: But if I'm the key to this power he craves, he'll hunt me to the ends of Faerûn.
Astarion: I need to take the fight to him.
Astarion: And I need you to help me.
Player: After we dealt with our tadpole problem, yes, I'll help you then.
Astarion: Once we deal with the tadpole, I'll be back to my nocturnal self. When you're being hunted by vampires, the dark is the worst place to hide.
Astarion: I need to deal with Cazador while I still have any kind of advantage over him.
Astarion: If you won't risk taking him on for my sake, think of the innocent souls he'll sacrifice in this ritual.
Player: We're done talking about this, Astarion. My decision is made.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Hail, friend. Fine day, isn't it?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Forgive me - you're in no mood to talk about the weather. Your journey here was a hard one, no doubt.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Is this your first time in Baldur's Gate?
Player: Yes, I heard the streets were paved with gold... the coin purses, too.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: A word of advice then - you might not get as warm a welcome as in days gone by.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Used to be you'd arrive knowing you'd a full belly and a warm bed waiting for you. Not any more.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: These days, there's barely enough to go around. Add the refugees on top and... well, folk aren't feeling too generous.
Player: Is there anything I can do to ease these people's burden?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: I've been asking myself the same question. I wouldn't be the first to interfere.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Some well-to-do's in the city donated enough to see the newcomers right for the time being. Only they didn't bother helping everyone else.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Locals going without while strangers feast - it's stoked the fire, all right. Some Baldurians are kicking up a fuss round the front of the barn as we speak.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: If I wasn't wearing this uniform, I'd walk round there and teach them a lesson they'd never forget.
Player: If the refugees have more than they need, it's only fair they give some back.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Too bloody right. But will they share? Not a chance.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Those refugees have been leeching on our city for too long. If we don't show them we mean business, they'll bleed us dry.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: We need to march round the front, and kill every last one of them. Let's see them eat our food with their guts on the floor. What do you say?
Player: Let's soak the earth with entrails, kill and kill again!

Skickpit: Piss off.
Player: It's pronounced: 'I tremble afore your awful majesty.'
Skickpit: I can call you other silly names, True Soul. Like arserag, or shitepot.
Skickpit: So like I said: piss off.
Player: Say that to me one more time, and I'll gut you.
Skickpit: Is that so? Well listen close, True Soul - I've got a new tune to whistle.
Skickpit: Piss. The drugh. Off.
Player: How about we show these slavers what deep gnomes are made of, instead?

Astarion: There you are, I was just thinking about you. And that delicious moment we shared the other night.
Player: The moment when you bit me?
Astarion: The very same. I've had this condition for two centuries, but truth be told? You were my first.
Astarion: In all these years, I've only ever fed on beasts. Drinking the blood of thinking creatures is a different thing entirely.
Astarion: You were delectable. And now I just can't help but wonder how the others taste.
Player: They might not be as open to the idea as I was.
Astarion: Alas. It doesn't hurt to ponder the question, though.
Astarion: I don't think they'd volunteer, of course, but it doesn't make me any less curious.
Astarion: Take Shadowheart, for example. She strikes me as having a heavy, enigmatic flavour - vintage port on two legs.
Astarion: But the gith? What in the hells would she taste like?
Player: Something exotic, surely? An Amnan liqueur?
Astarion: Ohh, that sounds very appealing. I'm almost convinced.
Player: This is still theoretical, right?
Astarion: Absolutely. A mere thought experiment.
Astarion: So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?
Player: I much prefer eating flesh to blood.
Astarion: I do appreciate your enthusiasm, but let's try to restrain ourselves a little.
Astarion: I just mean a sip of their blood. No mastication required.
Astarion: So - in the spirit of theoretical questions - if you had to take a bite from one of them, who would it be?
Player: Gale, no question.
Astarion: I'm all too familiar with Gale's blood, unfortunately. I can't recommend it.
Astarion: But the gith? What in the hells would she taste like?
Player: I'd prefer a beer, if it's all the same to you.
Astarion: Yes, heavens forbid we'd have an interesting conversation.
Astarion: Still, I am intrigued by the possibilities...

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Sounds pointless. Public opinion will hardly be swayed by such a small experiment.
Havkelaag: Not at first. But if the experiment proves successful, it must be repeated. Only then will we know if the findings are to be trusted.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Zevlor: Aradin didn't make it? Pity - but he might've got more of my people killed, if not for you.
Zevlor: Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him.
Zevlor: Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor.
Zevlor: And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
Player: What is this place?
Zevlor: A druids' grove, dedicated to the Oak Father, Silvanus. You'll find its keepers just as thorny, I fear.
Zevlor: Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out.
Zevlor: This attack will only strengthen their resolve.
Player: Why are they forcing you out?
Zevlor: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore.
Zevlor: They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside.
Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
Player: What brought you here?
Zevlor: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road.
Zevlor: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
: True
Player: That's sad - but it doesn't mean the druids owe you sanctuary.

He Who Was: Madeline's spirit is within reach. It is time to make her face trial, to make her suffer.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'd like to hear her story first - I imagine it's quite the tale.
He Who Was: Careful - for a serpent in life is a serpent in death.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Astarion: Well now, let's not throwing stones. Glass houses and all that.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: Don't blame others for what you did.
Madeline: You didn't see it. Didn't see what the Dark Justiciar did.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Yours is a classic tale of cowardice. Were you a character in a tale of mine, I would kill you off - immediately.
Player: You had the means to stop it - you chose not to. You let fear and cowardice rule you.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Hail, friend. Fine day, isn't it?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Forgive me - you're in no mood to talk about the weather. Your journey here was a hard one, no doubt.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Is this your first time in Baldur's Gate?
Player: It is. I can't believe I'm finally here.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Well, whatever you've heard - the reality might not be quite so rosy.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Used to be you'd arrive knowing you'd a full belly and a warm bed waiting for you. Not any more.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: These days, there's barely enough to go around. Add the refugees on top and... well, folk aren't feeling too generous.
Player: Sounds like that's your problem, not mine.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: If it were my problem, I'd do something about it. Instead they've stuck me guarding this door while they squabble over the donations.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Some well-to-do's in the city donated enough to see the newcomers right for the time being. Only they didn't bother helping everyone else.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Locals going without while strangers feast - it's stoked the fire, all right. Some Baldurians are kicking up a fuss round the front of the barn as we speak.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: If I wasn't wearing this uniform, I'd walk round there and teach them a lesson they'd never forget.
Player: The people of this city have grown selfish. They need reminding what true hardship is.
Nightwarden Minthara: We can be the reminder. Soft citizens make easy targets.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Too bloody right. They've gone soft behind those walls, forgotten what it's like to struggle, living hand-to-mouth.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: I say we march round there and slit a few bellies. Remind them how much worse things could be. What do you say?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: We need to march round the front, and kill every last one of them. Let's see them eat our food with their guts on the floor. What do you say?
Player: They're innocent people. You can't just kill them!

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Hail, friend. Fine day, isn't it?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Forgive me - you're in no mood to talk about the weather. Your journey here was a hard one, no doubt.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Is this your first time in Baldur's Gate?
Player: Yes. I'm almost entirely sure I'm a Baldurian.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: It's a fine city, isn't it? No better place to hail from.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Used to be you'd arrive knowing you'd a full belly and a warm bed waiting for you. Not any more.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: These days, there's barely enough to go around. Add the refugees on top and... well, folk aren't feeling too generous.
Player: I've got ways of making people share.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: The way things are going, it might well come to that.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Some well-to-do's in the city donated enough to see the newcomers right for the time being. Only they didn't bother helping everyone else.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Locals going without while strangers feast - it's stoked the fire, all right. Some Baldurians are kicking up a fuss round the front of the barn as we speak.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: If I wasn't wearing this uniform, I'd walk round there and teach them a lesson they'd never forget.
Player: If the refugees have more than they need, it's only fair they give some back.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Too bloody right. But will they share? Not a chance.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Those refugees have been leeching on our city for too long. If we don't show them we mean business, they'll bleed us dry.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: We need to march round the front, and kill every last one of them. Let's see them eat our food with their guts on the floor. What do you say?
Player: I will do better than mindless slaughter: it is not the answer.
