Raphael: Do you know what happens when a devil is struck down on this charming plane of existence?
Raphael: It returns to the hells - to the very point where it last stood before venturing to whichever devilforsaken plane it died on.
Raphael: In the case of our friend Yurgir, the orthon you so handily dispatched in the temple of Shar, he manifested in my House of Hope.
Raphael: He returned to me chastened but intact, his wounds healed, his body restored.
Raphael: He thought I would dismember him but he has his uses so instead I am reeducating him.
Astarion: We delivered the devil. Now I want what I'm owed - we had a deal.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: We had a deal - the orthon for information.
Raphael: Indeed we did. I discovered all there is to know about those scars of yours - it's a rather grim tale, even for my tastes.
Player: Are you sure you want to know, Astarion? Maybe it's best left in the past.
Astarion: Even if I wanted to walk away from all of this, I can't. Cazador won't let me.
Raphael: And why would he want to walk away? This is his destiny.
Raphael: As you know already, your precious skin is home to one part of a contract between the archdevil Mephistopheles, and your former master, Cazador Szarr.
Raphael: In full, the contract states that Cazador will be granted knowledge of an infernal ritual so vile it has never been performed.
Raphael: The Rite of Profane Ascension.
Raphael: It promises to be a marvellous ceremony. Very elaborate, incredibly ancient, and entirely diabolical.
Raphael: If he completes the rite, he will become a new kind of being - the Vampire Ascendant.
Raphael: All the strengths of his vampiric form will be amplified, and alongside them he will enjoy the luxuries of the living.
Raphael: The arousals and appetites of man will return to him, and unlike Astarion, he will have no need of a parasite to protect him from the sun.
Raphael: But the ritual has its price, as all worthwhile things do. Lord Cazador will need to sacrifice a number of souls, including all of his vampiric spawn, if he is to ascend.
Raphael: Imagine how he felt, then, when one of those precious spawn simply disappeared into thin air.
Raphael: The only missing ingredient is Astarion.
Raphael: You are the final piece he requires to complete the ritual - your scars bind you to it. Your soul will set off a very wave of death, bringing Cazador his twisted life.
Raphael: And that, my tragic and toothsome friend, is that. Now if you'll excuse me, I have business elsewhere.
NodeContext: [Tarik] snaps fingers at the end of the line.
Astarion: Hmm...
Player: Cazador is a piece of shit. We're going to stop him.
Astarion: Do you think it's so simple?
Astarion: What do you think I should do?
Player: I think you should run. If Cazador can't find you, he can't complete his ritual.

Astarion: How long do you think I can run? He has eternity to find me.
Astarion: He'll never leave me alone. I didn't think he would when I was just one more wretched toy for him to play with.
Astarion: But if I'm the key to this power he craves, he'll hunt me to the ends of Faerûn.
Astarion: I need to take the fight to him.
Astarion: And I need you to help me.
Player: After we dealt with our tadpole problem, yes, I'll help you then.
Astarion: Once we deal with the tadpole, I'll be back to my nocturnal self. When you're being hunted by vampires, the dark is the worst place to hide.
Astarion: I need to deal with Cazador while I still have any kind of advantage over him.
Astarion: If you won't risk taking him on for my sake, think of the innocent souls he'll sacrifice in this ritual.

Zevlor: This attack will only strengthen their resolve.

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: That kind of indoctrination and time-forced nurture violates the natural order. It invalidates the whole experiment.
Havkelaag: I won't bother to argue with you. An arboreal shaman can't be expected to understand the rigorous protocols of theoretical research.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

Havkelaag: I say - that wasn't a githyanki egg you were fiddling around with, was it?
Havkelaag: How would you like to sell it to the Society of Brilliance? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: This experiment is exactly the kind of evil you're trying to disprove.
Havkelaag: The pursuit of knowledge is neither evil nor good. Only in the application of such knowledge should one take on any moral imperative.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: No benefit could justify you inflicting such cruelty.
Havkelaag: Rigorous experimental methods demand we do not indulge our own emotional responses in the application of discomfort to our subjects.
Havkelaag: Only by the full, uninhibited application of psionic stimuli will we have a true measure of whether the child's innate evil has been cured.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.

NodeContext: Whispered

Lunkbug: It's my Beldron. He's still back there! I -
Lunkbug: Damn it, Laridda. We've lost enough of us. I'm not losing Beldron, too.
Lunkbug: Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.
Apprentice Laridda: Bug, please. True Soul Nere will - you know what he'll do.

Lunkbug: We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map.
Lunkbug: If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Player: I'll do what I can.

Wulbren Bongle: Good to see you. Wasn't sure you'd make it to the city. Regretting it yet?
Wulbren Bongle: I spent a lot of time thinking of worst case scenarios while I was locked in that cell you plucked me out of at Moonrise.
Wulbren Bongle: I didn't imagine anything as bad as this. The Gondians have handed Enver Gortash the means to bring about the end of liberty in Baldur's Gate.
Wulbren Bongle: And the citizens have rolled out the red carpet for their new tyrant.
Wulbren Bongle: Resistance fighters are few and far between - my Ironhands, what's left of the Harpers, and you. I hope.
Player: Gortash is a dead man - I have reasons of my own for taking him down.
Wulbren Bongle: As long as our objective is the same, the reason doesn't matter to me. We have a common enemy.
Wulbren Bongle: But neither of us gets what we want until we deal with our biggest obstacle.
Wulbren Bongle: The Steel Watch. They're a threat to you, me - and every man, woman and child in the city.
Wulbren Bongle: They act all civilised... servants of the people. But they only serve one man.
Wulbren Bongle: When he becomes Grand Duke, it will only get worse. Laws will change, freedoms will vanish, and soon you'll be accused and sentenced before you've even committed a crime.
Wulbren Bongle: And the fucking Gondians are to blame for all of it.
Player: The Gondians are just inventors. You can't blame them for Gortash's actions.
Wulbren Bongle: I can blame them for precisely that reason.
Player: I still don't buy it. Would you blame a mage for how the spells they wrote are used?
Wulbren Bongle: These Gondians are not poor, unknowing mages scribbling spell scrolls for Minute Meteors or Acid Arrows. They are complicit.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: Just kill them already - all this torture is pointless.
Malus Thorm: Behold, sisters, the very face of ignorance - one who mistakes tenderness for torture.
Malus Thorm: Go on. Acquaint the face of ignorance with the true object of our studies.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Astarion: He's just like Cazador - utterly insane.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
: True
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I sought purpose in the natural world - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: A GUTTERING CANDLE IN A UNIVERSE OF NIGHT

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.
Havkelaag: Enough of your kind have wreaked destruction on this plane for me to be confident in my assertion.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: Patience does not delay, it simply tempers virtue. Curtails it from excess.
Havkelaag: A cautious, hesitant instinct. One I am afraid we do not have time for.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Sounds pointless. Public opinion will hardly be swayed by such a small experiment.
Havkelaag: Not at first. But if the experiment proves successful, it must be repeated. Only then will we know if the findings are to be trusted.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.

Player: You think a few shadows could beat me?
Alfira: ...Wait. No one's told you?
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Wandering into the darkness was a stupid idea.
Alfira: And I regret it with every breath.
Alfira: I had to watch my friends, people who can barely hold a sword, try to fight a pack of murderous zealots.
Alfira: All I could do was run.
Player: Only fools fight an ambush. Better to live and strike another day - preferably to the neck.
Alfira: That means a lot, coming from you. You always seem to take everything in your stride.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: A strong weapon-arm and a bit of luck. That's all you need.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I'll do everything in my power to save them - you have my most solemn vow.

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: This experiment is exactly the kind of evil you're trying to disprove.
Havkelaag: The pursuit of knowledge is neither evil nor good. Only in the application of such knowledge should one take on any moral imperative.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Something called the Nightsong. Your notes were very interesting.
Player: Yet you seem no closer to retrieving the Nightsong? I read your notes - very interesting.
Balthazar: Interesting, and private. Give me one reason why I shouldn't have my creations kill you right now, thief.
Player: I received permission. Take it up with your peers at Moonrise, if you have an issue.
: True
Balthazar: ...Fine. I'll forgive your transgressions this time - there are much grander things at stake.
NodeContext: A pause before 'fine' - weighing up the player's fate.
Balthazar: The Nightsong is my finest creation - if I never exceed myself, I will still die happy. Not that I ever intend to do something as gauche as truly dying, of course.
Balthazar: Now, given your prying nature, I have work for you, as a scout.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: You need my help?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.
Player: For jobs like this it's good form to provide your operatives some extra resources.
: True
Balthazar: Fine. I will assign Flesh to aid you on your way. Ring this bell...
Balthazar: ...and he will come.
Balthazar: My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Actually, I have your mother.
Balthazar: What the...? Give me back my mother, this instant!
Player: No, I think I'll keep her.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: What lesson are you teaching these sisters?
Malus Thorm: The crux of our worship.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Loss.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Astarion: He's just like Cazador - utterly insane.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The sisters aren't ready. They'll make me sick instead of curing me.
: True
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: You do me an honour, but I am not worthy. Show me the way of Shar - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much since. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I heard there is so much goblin blood on your hands that it soaks their children's nightmares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You also killed Sarth Baretha. She was formidable.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: To business. I suspect you plucked something precious from the ghaik ship. Something that belongs to us.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The weapon. Give it to me.
Narrator: *The artefact stirs in your pocket. Right within your grasp, and desperate not to be relinquished.*
GROUP_Daisy: Don't do it. The weapon is how I protect you.
Lae'zel: Do it. Do not disobey the Inquisitor.
Player: Is the ghaik incursion not more important?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You mean the Grand Design? The restoration of the Illithid Empire? Why, it is of the utmost importance.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: But the weapon is the solution. I have heard it directly from Queen Vlaakith herself.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: It is how we will stop the mind flayers before they destroy us all.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Hand it over.

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you're planning to torture a child for a year?
Havkelaag: The child will be a better individual after my treatment than it ever would have been had it been raised in its natural environment.
Havkelaag: Any suffering it endures will therefore be worth it, for the child, perhaps for the whole of civilised society.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: An experiment like this will only confirm the surface dwellers' suspicion of us.
Havkelaag: Of course it won't. If anything, it will do quite the opposite. The academic institutions up here will finally be forced to take us seriously.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.

Havkelaag: Ah, a surface dweller.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to the Underdark: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: Perhaps not. Patience is important, but cannot impede the other virtues.
Havkelaag: Then we are in accord - the time for action is now.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Sounds pointless. Public opinion will hardly be swayed by such a small experiment.
Havkelaag: Not at first. But if the experiment proves successful, it must be repeated. Only then will we know if the findings are to be trusted.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Loss.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.

Balthazar: Finally, we can talk face-to-face.
Balthazar: Not just any True Soul would have succeeded in following my path through this place. You should be pleased.
Balthazar: I take it the breaking of my skeletons was an accident - the living are so clumsy, after all.
Player: I'm pleased to be of service, Balthazar.
Balthazar: Perhaps you can prove to me that you're more useful alive than dead. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Balthazar: But you're here now, and I may be able to put those limbs to work. You know what's at stake here, I take it?
Player: Judging by how you're cowering in here, your survival?
Balthazar: I do not cower - I plan. I command. I create.
Balthazar: General Thorm trusts me. He knows I will deliver. He knows I will stand by him long after all others wilt and fall.
Balthazar: You and all the rest have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Balthazar: You, Z'rell, all the rest... you have only one body with which to serve. I have as many as I care to make.
Player: As you mention serving Ketheric, he sent you to find a relic, no?

Balthazar: While you, an infinitely more humble servant, fulfil my command. I will put you to work - as a scout.
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him might just be the best way to gain access to Moonrise Towers.*
Narrator: *This necromancer has Ketheric's trust. Helping him could be just what you need to gain access to the man himself.*

: False
Balthazar: Telling you will not make the task any less perilous. Just obey, and use your ignorance as a shield. You should be adept at that already.
Balthazar: The Nightsong lends the General his strength, his invulnerability. It must be recovered, before his enemies attempt to exploit it.
Player: Sounds like you've good reason to be proud of the Nightsong - tell me more.

Balthazar: Words - even my words - are woefully insufficient. When you see for yourself, you will understand.
Player: What do you need me to do?
Balthazar: I do not need you, or your help. But you are here in spite of that, so I may as well make use of you.
Balthazar: The relic is close, but the way is barred and Shar's dead are... uncooperative. Clear the path for me - by blade, cunning, or whatever it takes.
Balthazar: I will remain here until you have succeeded, or fallen.
Shadowheart: I'd trust this gasbag about as far as I can throw him - which isn't far. But perhaps better to play along, for now.

Balthazar: ...and he will come.
Balthazar: My brother is no intellectual powerhouse, but he is strong, loyal and punctual. Should a fight turn against you, remember the bell.
Player: Actually, I have your mother.
Balthazar: What the...? Give me back my mother, this instant!

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world.
Halsin: It's no coincidence that you found me here, I'll wager? You're after a cure for this parasite.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: How did you come to study mind flayer parasites?
Halsin: A drow forced me to defend myself. Afterwards, I was able to study the parasite that slithered out of the corpse, see what drives these 'True Souls'.
Halsin: I had no idea anyone beyond their ranks was infected. You have my sincere sympathies.
Player: This magic you mentioned - it isn't normal for these parasites?
Player: Then everything we did here was hopeless.
Halsin: Patience. I can't just snap my fingers... but I know where the solution almost certainly lies.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: At least I know what to do now. Thank you.
Halsin: Wait - I could help you find a cure... but I need to settle matters here first.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: The other druids are dead, by my hand.
Halsin: What...? How? Why?! Explain yourself at once!
Player: They left me no choice. I had to defend myself.
Halsin: Then... then it is as you say. They forgot their principles; you had no choice. I will mourn them when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: It's too late to merely kill this horde's leadership - their forces are already marching. If you want me to help, you need to help me first.
Halsin: You must get ahead of them, muster the defences.
Player: You ask too much of me. I can't help you.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.

Havkelaag: Ah, a surface dweller.

Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.

Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.

Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you, too, follow the teachings of Bahamut. Why him?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: An experiment like this will only confirm the surface dwellers' suspicion of us.

Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.

Rugan: Listen. You look like you know how to handle yourself.

Rugan: Tell the fellow on the door 'little serpent, long shadow'. He'll take good care of you.

Rugan: It's fine. We'd be dead if they hadn't showed up. A little hospitality won't do any harm.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Loss.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: My magic has blinded me - I see now that Shar is the only path. Show me how - I beg of you.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.
: True
Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

He Who Was: Where lies your guilt?
NodeContext: Shadar-Kai speaks in a cold, calculated tone.
Madeline: The... Waning Moon...
NodeContext: Speak with dead style
Player: You look tough - good. It's more fun that way.
He Who Was: Stay your hand, and be on your way. I'll not raise mine against you.
Raven: *CAW.*
He Who Was: A fair point - perhaps this one could assist us.
He Who Was: The murdered lie silent. The raven asks - will you be their voice?
Narrator: *The raven, the piercings, the general malaise: this is a shadar-kai. Tales and songs featuring servants of the Raven Queen tend to be tragedies.*
Player: Why does the raven want to know?
He Who Was: He thinks you strong enough for the task at hand.
He Who Was: This woman tended a bar where she took her patrons, her friends, into her confidence - promised their secrets were safe with her.
He Who Was: Yet she turned their words into knives - and stabbed them in the back.
He Who Was: They died because of her - and to this day her victims lie unavenged.
Player: It sounds like she must be punished - thoroughly.
He Who Was: You see it as I do.
He Who Was: I seek a record of this one's crimes - written in her own hand.
He Who Was: Through it, I can summon her spirit - and force her to face trial for her crimes.
Player: That's some powerful magic - how do you do it? Can you show me?
He Who Was: Such spells are ancient secrets, and closely guarded - but I could be convinced to share them with an ally.
He Who Was: Your soul sparks with vengeance. With fury. This is your chance to torment a murderer. To make her suffer.
He Who Was: Will you take it?
Player: I will - what must I do?

Havkelaag: I say - that wasn't a githyanki egg you were fiddling around with, was it?
Havkelaag: How would you like to sell it to the Society of Brilliance? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You assume my people are evil, yet your research is built on sheer superstition.
Havkelaag: Enough of your kind have wreaked destruction on this plane for me to be confident in my assertion.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: That kind of indoctrination and time-forced nurture violates the natural order. It invalidates the whole experiment.
Havkelaag: I won't bother to argue with you. An arboreal shaman can't be expected to understand the rigorous protocols of theoretical research.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: A student, yes. Do please enlighten me.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.

Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.

Rugan: Thank the gods that's over. Wish you'd been with us when the beasts attacked on the road.

Rugan: Are any of my crew still alive out there?

Rugan: Damn it. I guess that's a no.
Rugan: Risen Road's more dangerous than ever. You're the first friendly face we've seen since Elturgard.
Player: Elturgard's a long way from here. Where are you heading?
Rugan: We're bound for Baldur's Gate - got some cargo to deliver. But we've a stop to make along the way.
Player: Where's that?
Rugan: Waukeen's Rest. It's just up the road. I'd be enjoying a mug of ale right now if those beasts hadn't jumped us.
Rugan: Listen. You look like you know how to handle yourself.
Rugan: You should meet my associates. We've got our own drinking spot by the tavern - invitation only.
Rugan: Tell the fellow on the door 'little serpent, long shadow'. He'll take good care of you.

Rugan: It's fine. We'd be dead if they hadn't showed up. A little hospitality won't do any harm.
Player: What's in the chest? Your cargo?
Rugan: Aye. The whole reason we're in this mess. Trinkets for some rich tosser in Baldur's Gate.
Rugan: He gets his shiny baubles, we get a handful of Tarenths.
: False
Player: The cargo. Give it to me. Or else.

: False

Havkelaag: Ah, a surface dweller.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to the Underdark: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: Perhaps not. Patience is important, but cannot impede the other virtues.
Havkelaag: Then we are in accord - the time for action is now.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: No benefit could justify you inflicting such cruelty.
Havkelaag: Rigorous experimental methods demand we do not indulge our own emotional responses in the application of discomfort to our subjects.
Havkelaag: Only by the full, uninhibited application of psionic stimuli will we have a true measure of whether the child's innate evil has been cured.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Loss.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: The goddess has greater plans for me than to submit to your scalpels.
: True
Malus Thorm: Another absence is your fate? But if you are not here to be cured, how will my sisters learn?
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Now whisper your questions, little wretch. But really quiet, and very clever. Concentrate.

: True
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Remember. Quiet as a mouse.
Player: I need to find the Orphic Hammer. Where is it?
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: Discovered an ancient gith prince in need of a saviour? The Orphic Hammer is the perfect tool for breaking all infernal chains.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: In the Archive. Down the corridor, past the debtors. OH! The debtors. They won't like you.
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: But I like you. I know I do, I think I do, I hope I do. I just need to ask one question, and I'll know for sure.

Questioner Sumera: You were adored, Minthara. Brought up from the darkness, and into the Absolute's light.
Questioner Jasin: She cherished you. But it wasn't enough - you were distracted by your own desires.
Questioner Sumera: Bloodlust. Murder. Chaos.
Questioner Jasin: And most damning of all, an unexpected weakness - a longing for acceptance, and affection. From a mortal.
Nightwarden Minthara: You have no right - hnngnn.
NodeContext: Through gritted teeth, holding back immense mental agony - cut off abruptly by a wave of psychic agony, which she reacts to with a pained grunt/sob
Questioner Sumera: We have every right.
Questioner Jasin: You are nothing.
Narrator: *Minthara's mind connects with yours. Not strong, as you remember it, but fractured... disintegrating.*
Questioner Sumera: Come to observe, True Soul? She is a lesson - none can rise so high that they cannot fall again.
Player: I expected her to be dismembered. Disappointing.
Questioner Sumera: When the body suffers, we retreat into the mind. But when the mind breaks, all is lost.
Questioner Sumera: We are erasing her.

: True
Questioner Sumera: No - this is our duty.
Questioner Jasin: Peace, sister. Let us observe the True Soul's methods - perhaps we can learn from them.

-SUBMIT-

Nightwarden Minthara: This thing, that speaks inside me - it has all but destroyed me. But... it fears you.
Nightwarden Minthara: Even so, I cannot resist it while my tormentors live.

Nightwarden Minthara: I will put my faith in you, and pretend to be their slave.

Varsh Ko'kuu: This hatchery is a place of solemn duty and care. No one approaches an egg without my permission.
Varsh Ko'kuu: Of course, a stranger from a strange crèche may have different customs. What brings you here?

Varsh Ko'kuu: Almost all of the eggs in this clutch have hatched. We await only one more, which is... taking its time.
Lae'zel: Failure at the first hurdle of existence. Most caretakers would crush it and be done.

: True

: True

Varsh Ko'kuu: They almost drowned me in the hatching pool. If it wasn't for the varsh of my clutch -
Varsh Ko'kuu: This one deserves the same chance.

Alfira: All I could do was run.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: You will stop this sick spectacle at once.
Malus Thorm: Sick. Quite. But on the cusp of a cure:
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Their blades are uneven. Efficient surgery will require further training.
Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: 'Only with sacrifice is mastery gained.' For the sisters to learn, you must submit.
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes. Submit I must, into the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

Player: Enough about the ritual. I have my own problems.

Rugan: Listen. You look like you know how to handle yourself.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.

Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Secrecy.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Gale: Gods, what living nightmare is this?
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.

Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Loss.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Astarion: He's just like Cazador - utterly insane.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes even you, one who walks faithfully in her shadow. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Sparring is vital to progress. Have them practice on each other.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Screaming and slashing, the sisters brutally murder each other.
Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.
Malus Thorm: Come, I will acquaint you with the Lady's dark-fingered embrace.
Player: I am not worthy! Please, show me how a master works - I would be honoured.
Player: I would rather acquaint myself - if you show me how.

Malus Thorm: Your diligence is exemplary. Very well: your own scalpel you will be.
